title: Spider-Man - Hunt For The Amulet
body:
Tony sends Peter on a mission to Rio De Janeiro to find and recruit a girl named Ava Ayala. But when he gets there, a lot of trouble happens when a power-hungry hunter is after her as well. Follows the MCU Timeline. Takes place a month after The Clash of The Avengers.

New Mission

(Peter’s POV)“Ned…Ned, you there buddy?"I say lightly patting my friend on the cheek."I had a crazy dream,” he groaned,“ We were at your house and Tony Stark was there.” He must’ve been so shocked…

Read more…

blog.name: avengers-generation
blog.title: Avengers: Generations
blog.description: After the creation of Captain America, many attempts have been made to re-create the super-soldier serum. In the 1950s, some of these attempts were a success. (Fanfic taking place post "Civil War". Original characters.)

title: Avengers: Generations
body:
Summary: After the creation of Captain America, many attempts have been made to re-create the super-soldier serum. In the 1950s, some of these attempts were a success. (Taking place post “Civil War”. Original characters.)

Chapter Summary: Tony, Rhodes and Peter get called to do recon on an old S.H.I.E.L.D. facility when one of its alarms goes off. They try to find out what’s missing.

Chapter 1

Iceland - 2017

The low rumble of the hover jet was soothing, as was the dark ocean beneath them. It was making staying awake more difficult for the team. The low lights in the cabin illuminated the sleepy, half-asleep faces.

Peter was curled up under a blanket, discarded homework on the table in front of him. His hair had grown a little long, the front wisps trailing over his forehead.  

Rhodes was in the row behind him. The small television in front of him flashing lights across his face. He had been fading in and out of sleep the whole ride.

Tony was at the back of the plane, straining to keep his eyes open. He was looking over the schematics and blue prints of the facility they were going to. Not that there was much to look at. There were so many blank spots with no information on what was in the room. And the prints were old. About 30 years old. There was no telling if something had changed since then.

“F.R.I.D.A.Y.” Tony said quietly.

“Yes, Mr. Star.”

“Search for more information on Site 10034 from S.H.I.E.L.D., what they gave us is laughable.”

“Searching. We’re also 20 minutes out. Should I wake the Mr. Rhodes and Mr. Parker?”

“Yes, and start the coffee pot. Please and thank you.”

The cabin started to be filled with grunting and slow shuffles. Soon all three of them were up, mugs of coffee in their hands and looking at the plan Tony had made up. They looked as the holograms rising out of the table in the cockpit.

“Mmm, no, not for you kid. I don’t want your growth stunted. Your Aunt May wouldn’t like that.” Tony gave Peter a stern look and took the mug, taking a sip. “That’s good. Have some juice. Vitamin D is good for you. Alright F.I.D.A.Y., what did you find?”

“Nothing Mr. Stark. There is no record of a Site 10034 in any of S.H.I.E.L.D.’s databases. All maps of the location show it as empty.”

“Well, that makes this more interesting.”

“So what do we think is there? Weapons? Secret jail? Hydra camp?” Rhodes asked.

“Unknown. All S.H.I.E.L.D. knows is that its one of their old facilities and that its been compromised. They’re sending agents in after we clear the area.”

“So what exactly do they want us to do…” Peter looked around at the blank plans, an equally blank expression on his face.

“Recon. Find out if there’s anyone still down there and if anything’s been taken.” Tony walked away from the table, heading towards the back of the jet.

“How do we know if there’s anything missing?” Peter wondered, following close behind.

“Look for a missing mantle piece. Now suit up, we’ve got to drop in.”

The hover jet humming was louder in the back near the drop door. All three men waited by the door for the go ahead to jump. The red light reflecting off all of their suits. Peter’s new jump suit was bulkier than he was used to. He fidgeted a bit, missing the easy flexibility of his other one.

“Stop that.” Tony said, he checked the map on his wrist screen. “We’re jumping in 20. Put your helmet on and get ready. You’re about to fly.” He closed his mask, Rhodes following his lead.

Peter took a deep breath. Shook off his nerves. He pushed his hair back. Slide on his helmet. And waited.

3. 2. 1. The green light turned on. The doors opened. And they jumped. Tony and Rhodes first, Peter a few moments later. Then, he was free falling.

Iceland was below them, a few lights visible down on the ground. Air rushed by him, but he could barely feel it through his suit. He looked around. Feeling so small compared to everything that was below him. He was amazed. He took a few moments to enjoy the view, before turning his attention to the ground below him.

“Karen, h-how’re doing?” His helmet’s screen lit up, showing his altitude, speed and mapping the route to the drop point.

“Right on target.” Peter stayed on course. Going through all the steps he was taught during his sky diving training. He could see his landing point. Tony and Rhodes were already on the ground, lighting it up for him. He was getting closer and closer.

“I’m ready. I can do this. I’m not going to fall like in training.” He said to himself.

“Good luck Peter.” Karen responded.

He released his parachute, and got pulled back up. He reached his legs towards the ground, and started to run along, burning off his momentum. He was 20 feet from the others when his toe got caught. He rolled the rest of the way to Tony’s feet, getting wrapped up in his parachute.

“Ow.” Peter squeaked. Tony look down at him, his mask pulled down and a blank expression on his face.

“Did you get that?” He asked.

“Oh ya.” Rhodes answered, his suit’s camera on and pointing at Peter.

“Perfect. Add it to the montage.” Tony laughed as he helped Peter get up. Once he was untangled they headed towards the site.

The valley they were in had no visible buildings. Darkness stretched out in front of them, the lights from the urban areas long gone. The low glow from the iron suits providing the only light. The stars shone down brightly, twinkling as they walked on.

“So where is it? Is what’s got taken the whole building!? Did they Ant-man it?” Peter wondered, excitement lacing his voice.

Tony lifted up his arm, scanning the area. A series of red beams glided over the landscape before displaying that nothing was found. “Well that’s not good.” Tony said.

“Is it just me, or is this starting to feel like a trap?” Rhodes said, opening his helmet’s mask.

“Either that or a really bad prank.” Tony continued to walk on, looking around the grass. “F.R.I.D.A.Y., scan for disturbances in the dirt and grass.” He lifted his arm and scanned the area again. This time a dozen places were identified. “Someone has definitely been here recently.”

“Is there anything in particular we should be looking for?” Rhodes walked over to Tony looking at the disturbance pattern that was on the hologram.

“Only one way to find out.” Tony activated his boosters, and rose into the air. “Stand back.” He lifted his hand, then began to incinerate all the grass in the area. Within a few minutes the whole area was clear of grass.

“Mmm. Let’s try this again.” Tony performed a final scan. This time the whole area lit up. Tony looked at the ground beneath his feet. He pondered for a second before blasting into the ground. An explosion knocked him back several feet. Rhodes and Peter rushing over, alert and ready for whatever it might be.

“What the hell was that?” Rhodes asked.

Tony got back to his feet, then walked straight to the hole in the ground. The three men slowly peered down, unsure of what they were going to find. Beneath the dissipating smoke was a metallic slab that disappeared into the soil.

“I think we found the building.” Peter whispered.

“Let’s get to the bottom of this.” Tony placed a small round device on the top of the metal slab. It beeped to life and began to emit short beams all along the slab and into the soil.

“What is that doing? What if the metal explodes again?” Peter asked, taking a step back form the hole.

“Its a scanner. It will tell us what part of the building this is and we can compare it to our subpar plans. Maybe then we can find a door.” Tony looked at his holographic map as the device beeped. The building blue print came up, highlighting the portion of the building they seemed to be on top of. Tony waved his hand, highlighting the entrances. A single surface one was displayed and two underground ones, presumably connected to tunnels or other buildings they didn’t have the plans to. “There’s the bugger.”

They hurried over to where the entrance should be, making quick work of the soil covering it with their lasers. In a few moments Tony lifter his hand, signalling them to stop. “Not any deeper, we don’t want a repeat explosion.” The team switched to air blasters and in a few minutes they had found a trap door.

They stared at it for a moment. Unsure if they should touch it. A quick scan revealed nothing.

“Well that’s not surprising. Here goes nothing.” Tony reached down for the handle, twisted it and opened the door. A hiss of air came out, releasing the seal that had been holding it shut. They peered down, finding a dark flight of stairs. Tony lead the way as they began to descent down the stairs. Lights turned on once Tony reached the bottom. They were standing in a short white hall, another door with a passcode at the end. Along the display they could read the words “Disarmed-Failure Sector 9.”

“Well that settles it. Something definitely happened here. Be on high alert.” Tony grabbed the handle and twisted the door. He stepped out onto a catwalk, a tidy common space beneath them. All of the furniture was in good condition, with not even a layer of dust on it. There were sets of couches, a small kitchenette and dinning table. Bookshelves ran along one wall, reaching all the way to the celling. There was a ping-pong table in the far corner, with a chalkboard on the wall next to it. The board had names and game scores recorded on it of an unfinished tournament.

“This is not what I expected.” Rhodes said, looking towards a piano that was right below the cat walk. Christmas sheet music was still on the stand.

“Its so homey. Oh! Look at that!” Peter pointed towards the ceiling. A series of ropes and monkey bars were hanging down, as well as a few hammocks. “This is so cool!” He reached out his arm, ready to shoot a web.

“Don’t!” Tony held Peter’s arm down. “Not until we clear the building.”

Peter slouched down, his disappointment not hidden by his helmet. Tony went back to the door and connected to the facility’s system. In a few moments he had the seemingly complete floor plan, divided into nine sectors.

“Alright team. It looks like we have to go through most of the sectors before we get to nine. Let’s make quick work of this.” He sent the plans to the other two and then they were off, making their way through the facility.

Off the common room they found two hallways with dorm like bedrooms coming off them. Neat and tidy, with very few personal items. Past the catwalk they went down another set of stairs and into another hall. There they found what looked like classrooms, and a gymnasium and workout space. Further in were more bedrooms, a movie theatre, kitchen, mess hall and laundry room. All were in good condition, and spotless, as if someone had just cleaned the spaces.

“Are we sure this was S.H.I.E.L.D.? It feels more like a weird family bunker.” Rhodes noted as he picked up a book that had been left open on a table. They were in the library. It covered three floors with a large atrium in the middle.

“We’ve only covered three sectors. It still has time to get weird.” Tony said, watching as Peter swung from floor to floor, looking at the titles of the books. He was having way too much fun.

They continued down the hall, reaching a set of industrial doors with ‘Sector 4’ written across them. Tony pushed against the doors, and they didn’t budge. There was no handle or knob to turn. Looking around Tony was confused, until the doors slid open in front of him. He looked over at Rhodes who had pushed the open button next to the door.

Stepping inside the team found themselves in a stark white hallway, with clinical lights over head. The door slid shut behind them, sealing with a distinct suction sound. There were four doors on each side of the hall, with numbers on each. As they walked past they could see patient rooms, each with a bed and its own set of medical equipment. A nurses’ station was at the end of the hall and another door. Through this one they found operating rooms, most of the equipment old and outdated but still in working order. They also found labs, offices and storage rooms.

“All clear in here too.” Rhodes reported back after looking over the physical therapy and rehab spaces. Tony and Peter had finished looking over the labs, and were waiting in front of the sector nine door.

“Only one more place to check.”  Tony said reaching towards the key pad that controlled the single door. It was shorter than the others, Tony and Rhodes would have to crouch down to enter. It was also marked with danger tape around its outline and protective gear lined a small closet next to it. There was nothing indicating what they might find behind the door.

They waited a moment, as the door got unlocked, a small ping signalling its opening. The seal broke, and the door sunk back into its frame before sliding to the side. Inside they could see another vacuum sealed door, with another key pad next to it.

“Seal your suits, and turn on your air masks. Be on high alert. We have no clue what’s past those doors.” They stepped into the space. Rhodes pressed the close button on the first door. The room sealed shut. Tony walked up to the next key pad, and pressed the enter button. The room’s air changed, becoming colder and thinner. The sensors on the suits adjusted, keeping the three men warm and breathing easily. Then the door opened.

Blue light covered the small room. It had two low tables and instruments and equipment lining the walls. Tony quickly scanned the space. They were alone.

“Let’s check the back space. This is the area that was taking up the most energy of the whole facility.” Tony led the way to the door at the back of the room. Pushing it open he found a large space, the same blue light filling the room. Along the walls were cylindrical tubes, each with their top covers opened to show a mat and a variety of wires and tubes.

Tony stepped in, looking more closely at each device.

“What are these? Is there supposed to be something in these? Is this an empty mantle piece?” Peter asked, looking closely at one of the beds.

“Are these what I think they are, Tony?” Rhodes asked, swinging one of the lids shut.

“Cryogenic tubes.” Tony replied.

“Cryogenic tubes? Why would S.H.I.E.LD. need those?” Peter asked, walking over to Tony.

“To keep super soldiers alive.” Tony pointed to the wall. A small photo and identification card was above the cryogenic tube.

body_abstract:
Summary: After the creation of Captain America, many attempts have been made to re-create the super-soldier serum. In the 1950s, some of these attempts were a success. (Taking place post “Civil War”. Original characters.)

Chapter Summary: Tony, Rhodes and Peter get called to do recon on an old S.H.I.E.L.D. facility when one of its alarms goes off. They try to find out what’s missing.

Chapter 1

Iceland - 2017

The low rumble of the hover jet was soothing, as was the dark ocean beneath them. It was making staying awake more difficult for the team. The low lights in the cabin illuminated the sleepy, half-asleep faces.

Peter was curled up under a blanket, discarded homework on the table in front of him. His hair had grown a little long, the front wisps trailing over his forehead.  

Rhodes was in the row behind him. The small television in front of him flashing lights across his face. He had been fading in and out of sleep the whole ride.

Tony was at the back of the plane, straining to keep his eyes open. He was looking over the schematics and blue prints of the facility they were going to. Not that there was much to look at. There were so many blank spots with no information on what was in the room. And the prints were old. About 30 years old. There was no telling if something had changed since then.

“F.R.I.D.A.Y.” Tony said quietly.

“Yes, Mr. Star.”

“Search for more information on Site 10034 from S.H.I.E.L.D., what they gave us is laughable.”

“Searching. We’re also 20 minutes out. Should I wake the Mr. Rhodes and Mr. Parker?”

“Yes, and start the coffee pot. Please and thank you.”

The cabin started to be filled with grunting and slow shuffles. Soon all three of them were up, mugs of coffee in their hands and looking at the plan Tony had made up. They looked as the holograms rising out of the table in the cockpit.

“Mmm, no, not for you kid. I don’t want your growth stunted. Your Aunt May wouldn’t like that.” Tony gave Peter a stern look and took the mug, taking a sip. “That’s good. Have some juice. Vitamin D is good for you. Alright F.I.D.A.Y., what did you find?”

“Nothing Mr. Stark. There is no record of a Site 10034 in any of S.H.I.E.L.D.’s databases. All maps of the location show it as empty.”

“Well, that makes this more interesting.”

“So what do we think is there? Weapons? Secret jail? Hydra camp?” Rhodes asked.

“Unknown. All S.H.I.E.L.D. knows is that its one of their old facilities and that its been compromised. They’re sending agents in after we clear the area.”

“So what exactly do they want us to do…” Peter looked around at the blank plans, an equally blank expression on his face.

“Recon. Find out if there’s anyone still down there and if anything’s been taken.” Tony walked away from the table, heading towards the back of the jet.

“How do we know if there’s anything missing?” Peter wondered, following close behind.

“Look for a missing mantle piece. Now suit up, we’ve got to drop in.”

The hover jet humming was louder in the back near the drop door. All three men waited by the door for the go ahead to jump. The red light reflecting off all of their suits. Peter’s new jump suit was bulkier than he was used to. He fidgeted a bit, missing the easy flexibility of his other one.

“Stop that.” Tony said, he checked the map on his wrist screen. “We’re jumping in 20. Put your helmet on and get ready. You’re about to fly.” He closed his mask, Rhodes following his lead.

Peter took a deep breath. Shook off his nerves. He pushed his hair back. Slide on his helmet. And waited.

3. 2. 1. The green light turned on. The doors opened. And they jumped. Tony and Rhodes first, Peter a few moments later. Then, he was free falling.

Iceland was below them, a few lights visible down on the ground. Air rushed by him, but he could barely feel it through his suit. He looked around. Feeling so small compared to everything that was below him. He was amazed. He took a few moments to enjoy the view, before turning his attention to the ground below him.

“Karen, h-how’re doing?” His helmet’s screen lit up, showing his altitude, speed and mapping the route to the drop point.

“Right on target.” Peter stayed on course. Going through all the steps he was taught during his sky diving training. He could see his landing point. Tony and Rhodes were already on the ground, lighting it up for him. He was getting closer and closer.

“I’m ready. I can do this. I’m not going to fall like in training.” He said to himself.

“Good luck Peter.” Karen responded.

He released his parachute, and got pulled back up. He reached his legs towards the ground, and started to run along, burning off his momentum. He was 20 feet from the others when his toe got caught. He rolled the rest of the way to Tony’s feet, getting wrapped up in his parachute.

“Ow.” Peter squeaked. Tony look down at him, his mask pulled down and a blank expression on his face.

“Did you get that?” He asked.

“Oh ya.” Rhodes answered, his suit’s camera on and pointing at Peter.

“Perfect. Add it to the montage.” Tony laughed as he helped Peter get up. Once he was untangled they headed towards the site.

The valley they were in had no visible buildings. Darkness stretched out in front of them, the lights from the urban areas long gone. The low glow from the iron suits providing the only light. The stars shone down brightly, twinkling as they walked on.

They stared at it for a moment. Unsure if they should touch it. A quick scan revealed nothing.

“Well that’s not surprising. Here goes nothing.” Tony reached down for the handle, twisted it and opened the door. A hiss of air came out, releasing the seal that had been holding it shut. They peered down, finding a dark flight of stairs. Tony lead the way as they began to descent down the stairs. Lights turned on once Tony reached the bottom. They were standing in a short white hall, another door with a passcode at the end. Along the display they could read the words “Disarmed-Failure Sector 9.”

“Well that settles it. Something definitely happened here. Be on high alert.” Tony grabbed the handle and twisted the door. He stepped out onto a catwalk, a tidy common space beneath them. All of the furniture was in good condition, with not even a layer of dust on it. There were sets of couches, a small kitchenette and dinning table. Bookshelves ran along one wall, reaching all the way to the celling. There was a ping-pong table in the far corner, with a chalkboard on the wall next to it. The board had names and game scores recorded on it of an unfinished tournament.

“This is not what I expected.” Rhodes said, looking towards a piano that was right below the cat walk. Christmas sheet music was still on the stand.

“Its so homey. Oh! Look at that!” Peter pointed towards the ceiling. A series of ropes and monkey bars were hanging down, as well as a few hammocks. “This is so cool!” He reached out his arm, ready to shoot a web.

“Don’t!” Tony held Peter’s arm down. “Not until we clear the building.”

Peter slouched down, his disappointment not hidden by his helmet. Tony went back to the door and connected to the facility’s system. In a few moments he had the seemingly complete floor plan, divided into nine sectors.

“Alright team. It looks like we have to go through most of the sectors before we get to nine. Let’s make quick work of this.” He sent the plans to the other two and then they were off, making their way through the facility.

Off the common room they found two hallways with dorm like bedrooms coming off them. Neat and tidy, with very few personal items. Past the catwalk they went down another set of stairs and into another hall. There they found what looked like classrooms, and a gymnasium and workout space. Further in were more bedrooms, a movie theatre, kitchen, mess hall and laundry room. All were in good condition, and spotless, as if someone had just cleaned the spaces.

“Are we sure this was S.H.I.E.L.D.? It feels more like a weird family bunker.” Rhodes noted as he picked up a book that had been left open on a table. They were in the library. It covered three floors with a large atrium in the middle.

“We’ve only covered three sectors. It still has time to get weird.” Tony said, watching as Peter swung from floor to floor, looking at the titles of the books. He was having way too much fun.

They continued down the hall, reaching a set of industrial doors with ‘Sector 4’ written across them. Tony pushed against the doors, and they didn’t budge. There was no handle or knob to turn. Looking around Tony was confused, until the doors slid open in front of him. He looked over at Rhodes who had pushed the open button next to the door.

Stepping inside the team found themselves in a stark white hallway, with clinical lights over head. The door slid shut behind them, sealing with a distinct suction sound. There were four doors on each side of the hall, with numbers on each. As they walked past they could see patient rooms, each with a bed and its own set of medical equipment. A nurses’ station was at the end of the hall and another door. Through this one they found operating rooms, most of the equipment old and outdated but still in working order. They also found labs, offices and storage rooms.

“All clear in here too.” Rhodes reported back after looking over the physical therapy and rehab spaces. Tony and Peter had finished looking over the labs, and were waiting in front of the sector nine door.

“Only one more place to check.”  Tony said reaching towards the key pad that controlled the single door. It was shorter than the others, Tony and Rhodes would have to crouch down to enter. It was also marked with danger tape around its outline and protective gear lined a small closet next to it. There was nothing indicating what they might find behind the door.

They waited a moment, as the door got unlocked, a small ping signalling its opening. The seal broke, and the door sunk back into its frame before sliding to the side. Inside they could see another vacuum sealed door, with another key pad next to it.

“Seal your suits, and turn on your air masks. Be on high alert. We have no clue what’s past those doors.” They stepped into the space. Rhodes pressed the close button on the first door. The room sealed shut. Tony walked up to the next key pad, and pressed the enter button. The room’s air changed, becoming colder and thinner. The sensors on the suits adjusted, keeping the three men warm and breathing easily. Then the door opened.

Blue light covered the small room. It had two low tables and instruments and equipment lining the walls. Tony quickly scanned the space. They were alone.

“Let’s check the back space. This is the area that was taking up the most energy of the whole facility.” Tony led the way to the door at the back of the room. Pushing it open he found a large space, the same blue light filling the room. Along the walls were cylindrical tubes, each with their top covers opened to show a mat and a variety of wires and tubes.

Tony stepped in, looking more closely at each device.

“What are these? Is there supposed to be something in these? Is this an empty mantle piece?” Peter asked, looking closely at one of the beds.

“Are these what I think they are, Tony?” Rhodes asked, swinging one of the lids shut.

“Cryogenic tubes.” Tony replied.

“Cryogenic tubes? Why would S.H.I.E.LD. need those?” Peter asked, walking over to Tony.

“To keep super soldiers alive.” Tony pointed to the wall. A small photo and identification card was above the cryogenic tube.

Chapter 1

Iceland - 2017

Peter was curled up under a blanket, discarded homework on the table in front of him. His hair had grown a little long, the front wisps trailing over his forehead.  

Rhodes was in the row behind him. The small television in front of him flashing lights across his face. He had been fading in and out of sleep the whole ride.

There were so many blank spots with no information on what was in the room. And the prints were old. About 30 years old. There was no telling if something had changed since then.

“F.R.I.D.A.Y.” Tony said quietly.

“Yes, Mr. Star.”

“Search for more information on Site 10034 from S.H.I.E.L.D., what they gave us is laughable.”

“Searching. We’re also 20 minutes out. Should I wake the Mr. Rhodes and Mr. Parker?”

“Yes, and start the coffee pot. Please and thank you.”

The cabin started to be filled with grunting and slow shuffles. Soon all three of them were up, mugs of coffee in their hands and looking at the plan Tony had made up. They looked as the holograms rising out of the table in the cockpit.

“Mmm, no, not for you kid. I don’t want your growth stunted. Your Aunt May wouldn’t like that.” Tony gave Peter a stern look and took the mug, taking a sip. “That’s good. Have some juice. Vitamin D is good for you. Alright F.I.D.A.Y., what did you find?”

“Nothing Mr. Stark. There is no record of a Site 10034 in any of S.H.I.E.L.D.’s databases. All maps of the location show it as empty.”

“Well, that makes this more interesting.”

“So what do we think is there? Weapons? Secret jail? Hydra camp?” Rhodes asked.

“Unknown. All S.H.I.E.L.D. knows is that its one of their old facilities and that its been compromised. They’re sending agents in after we clear the area.”

“So what exactly do they want us to do…” Peter looked around at the blank plans, an equally blank expression on his face.

“Recon. Find out if there’s anyone still down there and if anything’s been taken.” Tony walked away from the table, heading towards the back of the jet.

“How do we know if there’s anything missing?” Peter wondered, following close behind.

“Look for a missing mantle piece. Now suit up, we’ve got to drop in.”

The hover jet humming was louder in the back near the drop door. All three men waited by the door for the go ahead to jump. The red light reflecting off all of their suits. Peter’s new jump suit was bulkier than he was used to. He fidgeted a bit, missing the easy flexibility of his other one.

“Stop that.” Tony said, he checked the map on his wrist screen. “We’re jumping in 20. Put your helmet on and get ready. You’re about to fly.” He closed his mask, Rhodes following his lead.

Peter took a deep breath. Shook off his nerves. He pushed his hair back. Slide on his helmet. And waited.

3. 2. 1. The green light turned on. The doors opened. And they jumped. Tony and Rhodes first, Peter a few moments later. Then, he was free falling.

Iceland was below them, a few lights visible down on the ground. Air rushed by him, but he could barely feel it through his suit. He looked around. Feeling so small compared to everything that was below him. He was amazed. He took a few moments to enjoy the view, before turning his attention to the ground below him.

“Karen, h-how’re doing?” His helmet’s screen lit up, showing his altitude, speed and mapping the route to the drop point.

“Right on target.” Peter stayed on course. Going through all the steps he was taught during his sky diving training. He could see his landing point. Tony and Rhodes were already on the ground, lighting it up for him. He was getting closer and closer.

“I’m ready. I can do this. I’m not going to fall like in training.” He said to himself.

“Good luck Peter.” Karen responded.

He released his parachute, and got pulled back up. He reached his legs towards the ground, and started to run along, burning off his momentum. He was 20 feet from the others when his toe got caught. He rolled the rest of the way to Tony’s feet, getting wrapped up in his parachute.

“Ow.” Peter squeaked. Tony look down at him, his mask pulled down and a blank expression on his face.

“Did you get that?” He asked.

“Oh ya.” Rhodes answered, his suit’s camera on and pointing at Peter.

“Perfect. Add it to the montage.” Tony laughed as he helped Peter get up. Once he was untangled they headed towards the site.

The valley they were in had no visible buildings. Darkness stretched out in front of them, the lights from the urban areas long gone. The low glow from the iron suits providing the only light. The stars shone down brightly, twinkling as they walked on.

“So where is it? Is what’s got taken the whole building!? Did they Ant-man it?” Peter wondered, excitement lacing his voice.

Tony lifted up his arm, scanning the area. A series of red beams glided over the landscape before displaying that nothing was found. “Well that’s not good.” Tony said.

“Is it just me, or is this starting to feel like a trap?” Rhodes said, opening his helmet’s mask.

“Either that or a really bad prank.” Tony continued to walk on, looking around the grass. “F.R.I.D.A.Y., scan for disturbances in the dirt and grass.” He lifted his arm and scanned the area again. This time a dozen places were identified. “Someone has definitely been here recently.”

“Is there anything in particular we should be looking for?” Rhodes walked over to Tony looking at the disturbance pattern that was on the hologram.

“Only one way to find out.” Tony activated his boosters, and rose into the air. “Stand back.” He lifted his hand, then began to incinerate all the grass in the area. Within a few minutes the whole area was clear of grass.

“Mmm. Let’s try this again.” Tony performed a final scan. This time the whole area lit up. Tony looked at the ground beneath his feet. He pondered for a second before blasting into the ground. An explosion knocked him back several feet. Rhodes and Peter rushing over, alert and ready for whatever it might be.

“What the hell was that?” Rhodes asked.

Tony got back to his feet, then walked straight to the hole in the ground. The three men slowly peered down, unsure of what they were going to find. Beneath the dissipating smoke was a metallic slab that disappeared into the soil.

“I think we found the building.” Peter whispered.

“Let’s get to the bottom of this.” Tony placed a small round device on the top of the metal slab. It beeped to life and began to emit short beams all along the slab and into the soil.

“What is that doing? What if the metal explodes again?” Peter asked, taking a step back form the hole.

The board had names and game scores recorded on it of an unfinished tournament.
